title: Wayne Rooney's arrival can't come soon enough for Derby after abject defeat by Charlton
text:
Judging by Saturday’s abject surrender at The Valley, the Wayne Rooney era at Derby cannot come soon enough.

Out-fought by Charlton’s hungry and ambitious team of loanees and players with a point to prove, and out-thought by Lee Bowyer’s canny tactical insight.

It may have been a throwaway comment, but Charlton wing-back Jake Forster-Caskey summed up Derby’s rudderless display best. ‘In the end it was almost an easy win.’ he said. ‘We outworked them throughout the game and we didn’t give them time on the ball. That was really evident.’

Wayne Rooney has agreed to join Philip Cocu's Derby County as a player-coach in January

Easy? For a newly promoted side who lost some of their best players against a club that came within a play-off final defeat of stepping out in the Premier League this season?

Derby’s ambitions far out-strip those of Charlton — at least off the pitch, hence the signing of Rooney.

With his time Stateside coming to an end on Saturday with defeat in the MLS play-offs, the former England captain is now free to bring forward his arrival in the east Midlands from the original January schedule. How Derby need him. And quickly.

Macauley Bonne celebrates after scoring the opening goal in Charlton's 3-0 win over Derby

A Macauley Bonne strike on the turn, a Naby Sarr header from a corner and a glorious 20-yard curler from on-loan Chelsea midfielder Conor Gallagher eased Charlton to only their second victory since August, yet it could have been so many more.

Like his manager Phillip Cocu, a Dutch master outwitted by Bowyer’s impressive tinkering to nullify the opposition’s strengths, Derby defender Curtis Davies was at a loss to explain his side’s awful attitude and desire.

Davies said: ‘I wish I could put my finger on it. Charlton have a very energetic midfield. They get about the pitch and we couldn’t match them. We didn’t make them work hard enough for their goals or create anything at the other end.’
